Body: Zipfâ€™s law, as I understand it, is not really about languages, but about statistics and probability. It is just one of several formulations of the fact that many non-arbitrary sequences of numbers (frequency of words in a given corpus; population size of cites in relation to their rank; annual turnover of ranked companies; etc., etc.) are not evenly distributed along a decimal scale, but are more or less evenly distributed along a logarithmic scale. As such, it ought to work with all language corpora, including texts that avoid the use of certain letters.
